question: The Induced drag of an aero plane

choices.choice: is independent of the airspeed
decreases with increasing airspeed
increases with increasing airspeed

subject: Navigation

question: The stalling speed or the minimum steady flight speed at which the aero plane is controllable in landing configuration is abbreviated as

choices.choice: Vs1
Vs
Vso

subject: Navigation

question: Regarding take-off, the take-off decision speed V1:

choices.choice: is the airspeed on the ground at which the pilot is assumed to have made a decision to continue or discontinue the take-off
is an airspeed at which the aero plane is airborne but below 35ft and the pilot is assumed to have made a decision to continue or discontinue the take-off
is the airspeed of the aero plane upon reaching 35ft above the take-off surface

subject: Navigation

question: An increase in atmospheric pressure has, among other things, the following consequences on landing performance:

choices.choice: a reduced landing distance and improved go-around performance
an increased landing distance and improved go-around performance
an increased landing distance and degraded go-around performance

subject: Navigation

question: An increase in atmospheric pressure has, among other things, the following consequences on take-off performance:

choices.choice: a reduced take-off distance and degraded initial climb performance
a reduced take-off distance and improved initial climb perfomrance
an increased take-off distance and degraded initial climb performance

subject: Navigation

question: However does the thrust of fixed propeller vary during take-off run? The thrust

choices.choice: has no change during take-off and climb
increases slightly while the aero plane speed builds up
decreases slightly while the aero plane speed builds up

subject: Navigation

question: A constant headwind component

choices.choice: increases the angle of flight-path during climb
increases the maximum endurance
increases the best rate of climb

subject: Navigation

question: Assuming that the required lift exists, which forces determine an aero plane’s angle of climb?

choices.choice: Thrust and drag only
Weight, drag and thrust
Weight and drag only

subject: Navigation

question: How does the beat angle of climb and best rate of climb vary with increasing altitude?

choices.choice: Best angle of climb increases while best rate of climb decreases
Best angle of climb decreases while best rate of climb increases
Both decrease

subject: Navigation

question: The “climb gradient” is defined as the ratio of

choices.choice: the increase of altitude to distance over ground expressed as a percentage
the increase of altitude to horizontal air distance expressed as a percentage
true airspeed to rate of climb

subject: Navigation

question: A higher outside air temperature

choices.choice: increases the angle of climb but decreases the rate of climb
reduces the angle and the rate of climb
does not have any noticeable effect on climb performance

subject: Navigation

question: At a given mass, the stalling speed of a twin engine aircraft is 100kt in the landing configuration. The minimum speed a pilot must maintain in short final is:

choices.choice: 125kt
115kt
130kt

subject: Navigation

question: A multi engine aero plane is flying at the minimum control speed (Vmca). which parameter(s) must be maintainable after engine failure?

choices.choice: Altitude
Straight flight
Heading, altitude and a positive rate of climb of 100ft/min

subject: Navigation

question: The critical engine inoperative

choices.choice: does not affect the aero plane performance since it is independent of the power plant
increases the power required because of the greater drag caused by the wind milling engine and the compensation for the yaw effect
decreases the power required because of the lower drag caused by the wind milling engine

subject: Navigation

question: The speed V1 is defined as

choices.choice: take-off decision speed
engine failure speed
take-off climb speed

subject: Navigation

question: The speed VIo is defined as

choices.choice: landing gear operating speed
long distance operating speed
lift off speed

subject: Navigation

question: The result of a higher flap setting up to the optimum at take-off is

choices.choice: an increased acceleration
a shorter ground roll
a higher V1

subject: Navigation

question: Changing the take-off flap setting from flap15° to flap 5° will normally result in:

choices.choice: a longer take-off distance and a better climb
a better climb and an equal take-off distance
a shorter take-off distance and an equal climb

subject: Navigation

question: Which of the following speeds can be limited by the “maximum tyre speed”?

choices.choice: Lift-off groundspeed
Lift-off TAS
Lift-off IAS

subject: Navigation

question: If other factors are unchanged, the fuel mileage (nautical milers per kg) is

choices.choice: lower with an aft center of gravity position
independent from the center of gravity position
lower with a forward center of gravity position

subject: Navigation

question: When the outside air temperature increases, then

choices.choice: the field limited take-off mass and the climb limited take-off mass increases
the field limited take-off mass increases but the climb-limited take-off mass decreases
the field length limited take-off mass and the climb limited take-off mass decreases

subject: Navigation

question: What is the effect of a head wind component, compared to still air, on the maximum range speed (IAS) and the speed for maximum climb angle respectively?

choices.choice: Maximum range speed decreases and maximum climb angle speed decreases
Maximum range speed increases and maximum climb angle speed stays constant
Maximum range speed decreases and maximum climb angle speed increases

subject: Navigation

question: What is the advantage of a balance field length condition?

choices.choice: A balanced field length provides the greatest margin between "net" and "gross" take-off flight paths
A balanced field length gives the minimum required filed length in the event of an engine failure
A balanced take-off provides the lowest elevator input force requirements for rotation

subject: Navigation

question: Which of the following factors favours the selection of a low flap setting for the take-off?

choices.choice: High field elevation, distance obstacles in the climb-out path, long runway and a high ambient tamperature
High field elevation, no obstacles in the climb-out path, low ambient temperature and short runway
Low field elevation, no obstacles in the climb-out path, short runway and a low ambient temperature

subject: Navigation

question: The stop way is an area which allows an increase only in:

choices.choice: the accelerate-stop distance available
the take-off distance available
the take-off run available

subject: Navigation

question: Provided all other parameters stay constant. Which of the following alternatives will decrease the take-off ground run?

choices.choice: Decreased take-off mass, increased pressure altitude, increased temperature
Decreased take-off mass, increased density, increased flap setting
Increased outside air temperature, decreased pressure altitude, decreased flap setting

subject: Navigation

question: During the flight preparation a pilot makes a mistake by selecting a V1 greater than the required. Which problem will occur when the engine fails at a speed immediately above the correct value of V1?

choices.choice: The one engine out take-off distance required may exceed the take-off distance available
The stop distance required will exceed the stop distance available
V 2 may be too high so that climb performance decreases

subject: Navigation

question: Which statement regarding V1 is correct?

choices.choice: The V1 correction for up-slope is negative
When determining the V1, reverse thrust is only allowed to be taken into account on the remaining symmetric engines
V1 is not allowed to be greater than Vr

subject: Navigation

question: IF the antiskid system is inoperative, which of the following statements is true?

choices.choice: The accelerate stop distances decreases
The accelerate stop distance increases
Take-off with antiskid inoperative is not permitted

subject: Navigation

question: In the event of engine failure below V1, the first action to be taken by the pilot in order to decelerate the aero plane is to:

choices.choice: deploy air brakes or spoilers
reduce the engine thrust
reverse engine thrust

subject: Navigation

question: In which of the following distances can the length of a stop way be included?

choices.choice: In the one-engine failure case, take-off distance
In the all-engine take-off distance
In the accelerate stop distance available

subject: Navigation

question: If the field length limited take-off mass has been calculated using a Balanced Field Length technique, the use of any additional clearway in take-off performance calculations may allow

choices.choice: a greater field length limited take-off mass but with a lower V1
the obstacle clearance limit to be increased with no effect on V1
a greater field length limited take-off mass but with a higher V1

subject: Navigation

question: A “Balanced Field Length” is said to exist where:

choices.choice: The accelerate stop distance is equal to the take-off distance avaialble
The one engine out take-off distance is equal to the all engine take-off distance
The clearway does not equal the stop way

subject: Navigation

question: Which of the following sets of factory will increase the climb-limited TOM?

choices.choice: Low flap setting, low PA, low OAT
High flap setting, low PA, low OAT
Low flap setting, high PA, high OAT

subject: Navigation

question: If there is a tailwind, the climb limited TOM will:

choices.choice: increase
decrease
not be affected

subject: Navigation

question: The requirements with regard to take-off flight path and the climb segments are only specified for:

choices.choice: the failure of the critical engine on a multi-engines aero plane
the failure of any engine on a multi-engined aero plane
2 engined aero plane

subject: Navigation

question: The first segment of the take-off flight path ends

choices.choice: at completion of gear retraction
at reaching V2
at 35ft above the runway

subject: Navigation

question: The climb limited take-off mass can be increased by

choices.choice: selecting a lower V1
selecting a lower V2
a lower flap setting for take-off and selecting a higher V2

subject: Navigation

question: During take-off the third segment begins:

choices.choice: when acceleration starts from Vlof to V2
when flap retraction is completeed
when acceleration to flap retraction speed is started

subject: Navigation

question: For take-off obstacle clearance calculations, obstacles in the first segment may be avoided

choices.choice: by banking not more than 15° between 50ft and 400ft above the runway elevation
by standard turns - but only after passing 1500ft
by banking as much as needed if aero plane is more than 50ft above runway elevation

subject: Navigation
